docs.lead_paragraph: The magic number for the Boston Red Sox is zero. ''They can't call us the Boston Stranglers anymore,'' said Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, the winning pitcher, referring to the notion that Red Sox teams have often been criticized for choking. ''Now, someone else has gotta be called that.'' The Red Sox drubbed the Toronto Blue Jays today on a gentle fall afternoon before a near-capacity crowd of 33,358 in Fenway Park, and accomplished the feat with enough runs, according to Boyd, ''to win two games.''

headline.main: RED SOX CLINCH EAST DIVISION TITLE

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: This was the day the Yankees were supposed to begin in earnest their part of the American League East race. At this juncture, though, the Yankees' chances of winning that race seem only slightly less remote than the Mets' chances of losing their race in the National League East. In playing the Blue Jays in Toronto tonight, the Yankees begin a season-ending stretch of 25 games with teams that were supposed to be title contenders: seven with Boston and six each with Toronto, Baltimore and Detroit. However, the only legitimate contender among that five-team group appears to be the Red Sox. After last night's victory in Baltimore, they are seven games ahead of the Blue Jays, 11 ahead of the Yankees, 12 1/2 in front of the Tigers and a whopping 16 ahead of the Orioles.

headline.main: RED SOX TURNING EAST RACE INTO A ROUT

docs.lead_paragraph: A hearing to determine if the Boston Red Sox pitcher, Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, should face criminal charges stemming from a shoving incident with the police has been postponed until October. The police in Chelsea, Mass., said the hearing, originally set for today, was rescheduled for Oct. 28 in Chelsea District Court.

docs.lead_paragraph: Roger Clemens of the Boston Red Sox, who on Sunday pitched hitless ball for seven and two-thirds innings against the Texas Rangers as he won his eighth decision without a loss, yesterday was flown back to Boston from Cleveland as a precaution because of a swelling on the middle finger of his pitching hand. Clemens, the 23-year-old right-hander who set a major league record with 20 strikeouts against the Seattle Mariners on April 29, lost his bid for Boston's first no-hit game since 1965 when Oddibe McDowell singled with two out in the eighth inning. Clemens, who wound up with a two-hitter, will be examined today in Boston by Dr. Arthur Pappas, the team physician, and is expected to make his next scheduled start on Friday against the Twins in Bloomington, Minn.

headline.main: A Lost Way, a Lost Year for the Red Sox
headline.print_headline: A Lost Way, a Lost Year

docs.lead_paragraph: Mo Vaughn's eye and reputation took a hit when he was involved in a bar scuffle two years ago. Now accused of punching a man at a strip club, the star first baseman of the Boston Red Sox said today that he would do what it takes to prove his innocence. Scott Bird, 24, of North Olmsted, Ohio, said Vaughn punched him in the face while they were in the doorway of Tiffany's Cabaret at 2:30 A.M. Saturday. Charges have not been filed.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox star Mo Vaughn disputes Scott Bird's charge that he punched him at Cleveland strip club; holds he was at adjacent club (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox placed outfielder WIL CORDERO on waivers yesterday, a source told The Associated Press. If he is claimed before the deadline Thursday, the Red Sox could pull Cordero back, then work out a trade with the claiming team. If not, Boston could assign the 25-year-old outfielder to the minor leagues, release him or return him to his exile of ''administrative leave.'' Teams do not usually confirm when players are placed on major league waivers, routinely used to gauge trade interest and different from unconditional release waivers used to discard unwanted players.
